title: 111_hr639
content: The "Security Clearance Oversight and Accountability Act" requires reports on security clearances to be added to the National Security Act of 1947. The "Security Clearance Oversight and Accountability Act" mandates a quadrennial audit by the President on security clearance requirements in the executive branch, with results to be submitted to Congress. Additionally, an annual report on the security clearance process must be submitted to Congress by February 1st, detailing the number of government employees holding each security clearance level. The Security Clearance Oversight and Accountability Act requires an annual report to Congress detailing the number of government employees and contractors holding security clearances at different levels, as well as the processing time for security clearances in the intelligence community. The annual report to Congress must include data on the processing time for security clearances, including the time taken for the fastest 80% and 90% of determinations, the number of open investigations at different time intervals, and the percentage of reviews resulting in denial or revocation of security clearances. The annual report to Congress must include data on security clearance levels, incomplete investigations, and insufficient information for decision-making. The Director of National Intelligence may consider different security clearance levels. The Director of OMB must report to Congress annually on security clearance determinations that took longer than 1 year, including details on positions, contractors, investigating agencies, and causes of delays. Additionally, a report on metrics for adjudication quality must be submitted within 180 days of the enactment of the Act. Within 180 days of enactment, the President must submit a report to Congress on security clearance investigations and adjudications, including guidelines for adjudication quality, professional development plans for adjudicators, metrics for interagency clearance reciprocity, and investigation standards. Additionally, a clerical amendment is made to the National Security Act of 1947. The first audit under section 508(a)(1) of the National Security Act of 1947 must be completed by February 1, 2010.
